edu.biu.scapi.comm.twoPartyComm

Class SocketCommunicationSetup

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.biu.scapi.comm.twoPartyComm.SocketCommunicationSetup
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TwoPartyCommunicationSetup, org.apache.commons.exec.TimeoutObserver
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SSLSocketCommunicationSetup

    public class SocketCommunicationSetup
extends java.lang.Object
implements TwoPartyCommunicationSetup, org.apache.commons.exec.TimeoutObserver
    This class implements a communication between two parties using TCP sockets.

    Each created channel contains two sockets; one is used to send messages and one to receive messages.

    This class encapsulates the stage of connecting to other parties. In actuality, the connection to other parties is performed in a few steps, which are not visible to the outside user. These steps are:

    • for each requested channel,
    • Create an actual TCP socket with the other party. This socket is used to send messages
    • Create a server socket that listen to the other party's call. When received, the created socket is used to receive messages from the other party.
    • run a protocol that checks if all the necessary connections were set between my party and other party.
    • In the end return to the calling application a set of connected and ready channels to be used throughout a cryptographic protocol.
    From this point onwards, the application can send and receive messages in each connection as required by the protocol.

    Author:
    Cryptography and Computer Security Research Group Department of Computer Science Bar-Ilan University (Moriya Farbstein)

    • Method Detail

      • prepareForCommunication

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Channel> prepareForCommunication(java.lang.String[] connectionsIds,
                                                              long timeOut)
                                                                throws java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
        Initiates the creation of the actual sockets connections between the parties. If this function succeeds, the application may use the send and receive functions of the created channels to pass messages.
        Specified by:
        prepareForCommunication in interface TwoPartyCommunicationSetup
        Parameters:
        connectionsIds - Each required connection's name.
        timeOut - the maximum amount of time we allow for the connection stage.
        Returns:
        a map contains the connected channels. The key to the map is the id of the connection.
        Throws:
        java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException - in case a timeout has occurred before all channels have been connected.

      • prepareForCommunication

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Channel> prepareForCommunication(int connectionsNum,
                                                              long timeOut)
                                                                throws java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
        Description copied from interface: TwoPartyCommunicationSetup
        An application that wants to use the communication layer will call this function in order to prepare for communication after providing the required parameters.

        The constructor of the concrete classes should receive the data of the two parties participate in the communication. After that, this function initiates the creation of the final actual connections between the parties.

        Each connection has a unique name, that we call ID. This name used to distinguish between the created connections in order to make it easier and more convenient to understand what is the usage of each connection. In this function, the names of the connections are chosen by default, meaning the connections are numbered according to their index. i.e the first connection's name is "1", the second is "2" and so on.

        If this function succeeds, the application may use the send and receive functions of the created channels to pass messages.

        In this function, Nagle's algorithm is disabled; for cryptographic protocols this is typically much better. In order to use the Nagle algorithm, call the enableNagle() function.

        Specified by:
        prepareForCommunication in interface TwoPartyCommunicationSetup
        Parameters:
        connectionsNum - The number of requested connections.
        timeOut - the maximum amount of time we allow for the connection stage.
        Returns:
        a map contains the connected channels. The key to the map is the id of the connection.
        Throws:
        java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException - in case a timeout has occurred before all channels have been connected.

      • enableNagle

        public void enableNagle()
        Description copied from interface: TwoPartyCommunicationSetup
        Enables to use Nagle algorithm in the communication.

        By default Nagle algorithm is disabled since it is much better for cryptographic algorithms.

        Specified by:
        enableNagle in interface TwoPartyCommunicationSetup
